SHOULD the speed limit on New Jersey highways be raised to 65 miles per hour, or is the current limit, 55, right? Burning Fossil Fuel

The best reason I can think of to keep the limit where it is? Pollution. The faster we go, the more non-replaceable fossil fuel we burn, and the sooner we super-heat the planet, deplete the ozone layer and ruin the air, water, and land. We cannot see these effects, so we don't deal with them very well as a society. So keep it at 55; we'll live longer. RALPH COPLEMAN Lawrenceville Raise Gasoline Tax

Ralph: Rather than keep the speed limit unrealistically low, how about taxing gasoline so that it's priced commensurate with its toll on the environment? In real terms, gasoline is cheaper now than it was when I was a kid (and gas was 25 cents a gallon). If people thought twice about buying a Ford Explorer that gets 10 or 15 miles per gallon because of what fuel cost, maybe we'd have some impact on pollution.
JOSH DUBNICK Hopatcong Take Traffic Into Account

Let's be practical but fair. It is often difficult to do 45, let alone 55, on the Turnpike north of Newark in rush hour. South of the Raritan Plaza on the Parkway, the only vehicles driving 55 and under are the troopers. And don't forget the casino buses setting records. Raise the limit where we need it and keep it at 55 where traffic warrants. JEFFREY STRASHUN Hillside How About a Grace Limit?

No, we should not raise the speed limit. We should have a grace limit of 10 m.p.h. If you go over 55 you are speeding, but if you go over 65 you get a ticket and whatever goes with it. If you make it 65, people go 75. VERNON W. CAMPBELL Jersey City Don't Raise the Threshold

My business demands that I spend a lot of time on the road. On the major highways (the Parkway, Routes 80, 280, 78, etc.), I'll set my cruise control at 69 m.p.h. I have gone through perhaps 200 radar traps without being stopped. The unwritten rule seems to be, "Don't stop them for speeding under 70 m.p.h." Raise the posted limit and you most likely raise the ticket threshold. Why bother? Let's face it. The speed limit on our major highways is already 69 m.p.h. CHARLES BALETTI Essex Fells A Fact of Life
The 55 m.p.h. speed limit demonstrates that government bureaucrats and insurance company executives fail to understand a basic principle of transportation, proven through the ages: Faster is better.
TOM SWIFT Holmdel How to Talk Back
